title: 2 Methods to Spoiler Tag an Image on the Discord App on iOS and Android

steps.title: Tap the + symbol next to the text box.
steps.content: Tap the + symbol next to the text box. This will allow you to upload a photo to the Discord chat you're in.

steps.title: Select a photo to send.
steps.content: Select a photo to send. Simply tap or long-press the photo to select it.

steps.title: Tap the photo preview above the message box.
steps.content: Tap the photo preview above the message box. Several options will appear in the pop-up below the image.

steps.title: Check the Mark as spoiler box.
steps.content: Check the Mark as spoiler box. It's between the Remix and Remove file options. You may have to scroll slightly to see this option.

steps.title: Tap outside the menu or swipe down to close it.
steps.content: Tap outside the menu or swipe down to close it. The photo will now be grayed out with a white eye symbol over it. This signifies the image has been spoilered. [1] X Research source If you're sending multiple images in the message, you'll have to mark each one as a spoiler individually.

steps.title: Tap the blue send button.
steps.content: Tap the blue send button. Send your message with the image attached, and it will have the spoiler filter over it.

steps.title: Type || in the text box.
steps.content: Type || in the text box. When you send a link, it will automatically send an embed. If the embedded image is a spoiler, you can spoil it with Discord's text spoiler tags.

steps.title: Type || again.
steps.content: Type || again. The message should look like ||[link url]|| and the link should be highlighted in gray to signify it is going to be spoilered.

steps.title: Send the link.
steps.content: Send the link. The link will be spoiled with a black spoiler filter, and the image will be spoiled with Discord's blurred image spoiler filter. Alternatively, you can send the link surrounded by < and > to remove the preview embed. The link would then look like <[link url]> before you send it.
